feedstocks.name: Corn Stover
feedstocks.composition: Primarily composed of cellulose (35-40%), hemicellulose (25-30%), and lignin (15-20%)
feedstocks.key_specs: Corn stover is an agricultural residue consisting of the leaves, stalks, and cobs of maize plants left in a field after harvest. It is typically dry and fibrous.

products.name: Ethanol
products.composition: C2H5OH, typically 95-99% purity for fuel-grade ethanol
products.key_specs: Fuel-grade ethanol with specifications for water content, acidity, and purity. It should meet ASTM D4806 standards for denatured fuel ethanol.

feedstock_preparation.name: Feedstock Preparation
feedstock_preparation.description: The corn stover, which is an agricultural residue consisting of the leaves, stalks, and cobs of maize plants, is first collected and transported to the processing facility. Here, it undergoes size reduction through mechanical milling to increase the surface area, which is crucial for the subsequent enzymatic hydrolysis. The milled stover is then subjected to a drying process to reduce its moisture content, ensuring optimal conditions for the following pretreatment step.
feedstock_preparation.additional_info: Size reduction is typically achieved using hammer mills or knife mills. The target moisture content after drying is usually below 10%.

pretreatment.name: Pretreatment
pretreatment.description: The prepared corn stover is subjected to a pretreatment process to break down the lignin structure and make the cellulose and hemicellulose more accessible for enzymatic hydrolysis. This is typically done using a dilute acid pretreatment, where the biomass is treated with a dilute acid solution under high temperature and pressure. This process helps in solubilizing hemicellulose and partially depolymerizing lignin.
pretreatment.additional_info: Common acids used include sulfuric acid or hydrochloric acid. The pretreatment conditions are critical for maximizing sugar yield while minimizing degradation products.

enzymatic_hydrolysis.name: Enzymatic Hydrolysis
enzymatic_hydrolysis.description: The pretreated biomass is then subjected to enzymatic hydrolysis, where cellulase enzymes are added to convert cellulose and hemicellulose into fermentable sugars, primarily glucose and xylose. This process occurs in a bioreactor and is crucial for breaking down the polysaccharides into simple sugars that can be fermented into ethanol.
enzymatic_hydrolysis.additional_info: The enzymatic hydrolysis is typically conducted at moderate temperatures and neutral pH to optimize enzyme activity and stability.

fermentation.name: Fermentation
fermentation.description: The sugar solution obtained from enzymatic hydrolysis is then fed into a fermentation unit, where yeast or other microorganisms are used to convert the sugars into ethanol. This biological process occurs in anaerobic conditions and is a key step in the production of ethanol from biomass.
fermentation.additional_info: Saccharomyces cerevisiae is commonly used for fermentation. The process typically takes place over several days.

distillation.name: Distillation
distillation.description: The fermentation broth is subjected to distillation to separate ethanol from the mixture. This process involves heating the broth to vaporize ethanol, which is then condensed and collected as a concentrated product. Distillation is essential for achieving the desired purity of ethanol for fuel applications.
distillation.additional_info: The distillation process typically involves multiple stages to achieve high ethanol purity. Energy integration is crucial to minimize energy consumption.

dehydration.name: Dehydration
dehydration.description: The crude ethanol obtained from distillation is further dehydrated to remove any remaining water, achieving the high purity required for fuel-grade ethanol. This is often done using molecular sieves or azeotropic distillation techniques.
dehydration.additional_info: Molecular sieves are commonly used due to their ability to selectively adsorb water from ethanol.

waste_management.name: Waste Management
waste_management.description: The stillage and other waste streams generated throughout the process are managed through a combination of treatment and valorization strategies. Stillage can be processed to recover valuable by-products or used as animal feed. Wastewater is treated to meet environmental regulations before discharge.
waste_management.additional_info: Anaerobic digestion or aerobic treatment processes are often employed for wastewater treatment. The valorization of by-products can enhance the overall economic viability of the process.

Raw Corn Stover.name: Raw Corn Stover
Raw Corn Stover.description: Collected corn stover from agricultural fields, consisting of leaves, stalks, and cobs.

Prepared Corn Stover.name: Prepared Corn Stover
Prepared Corn Stover.description: Corn stover that has been milled and dried, ready for pretreatment.

Dilute Acid Solution.name: Dilute Acid Solution
Dilute Acid Solution.description: A dilute acid solution used for pretreatment.

Pretreated Biomass.name: Pretreated Biomass
Pretreated Biomass.description: Biomass with disrupted lignin structure, making cellulose and hemicellulose more accessible.

Cellulase Enzymes.name: Cellulase Enzymes
Cellulase Enzymes.description: Enzymes used to hydrolyze cellulose and hemicellulose into fermentable sugars.

Sugar Solution.name: Sugar Solution
Sugar Solution.description: A solution containing fermentable sugars derived from cellulose and hemicellulose.

Yeast Culture.name: Yeast Culture
Yeast Culture.description: Microorganisms used to ferment sugars into ethanol.

Fermentation Broth.name: Fermentation Broth
Fermentation Broth.description: A mixture containing ethanol, unfermented sugars, and by-products.

Crude Ethanol.name: Crude Ethanol
Crude Ethanol.description: Ethanol with impurities, requiring further purification.

Stillage.name: Stillage
Stillage.description: Residue from distillation containing water, unfermented sugars, and yeast biomass.

Fuel-Grade Ethanol.name: Fuel-Grade Ethanol
Fuel-Grade Ethanol.description: High-purity ethanol suitable for use as a fuel.

Treated Wastewater.name: Treated Wastewater
Treated Wastewater.description: Water that has been treated to remove contaminants before discharge.

Animal Feed.name: Animal Feed
Animal Feed.description: Nutrient-rich by-product suitable for use as animal feed.
